skills.name: Find missing angles on parallel lines using more than one angle fact

explanations.A: What do you know about corresponding angles on parallel lines? Is 120.001 the same as 120.000?
explanations.B: As the lines aren't quite parallel, they will eventually meet (or "intersect").
explanations.C: One definition of parallel lines is lines that will never meet (or "intersect")
explanations.D: "Intersect" means "meet". Any lines which are not parallel will eventually meet.

explanations.A: If the two lines were parallel these angles would have to be equal. What shape are these angles making?
explanations.B: Tom is wrong because the angles would be equal if the lines were parallel. Katie is correct, these angles are corresponding as they make an F shape.
explanations.C: What do we know about the F shape angles in parallel lines?
explanations.D: At least one of them is correct. Think about the F shape angles that we have here.

explanations.A: Parallel lines are "lines that never meet", they have the same direction.
explanations.C: Alternate is a type of angle relationship, as in "alternate angles are equal"
explanations.D: The red line is a transversal because it cuts across the two dotted lines.

explanations.A: Transversals intersect with at least 2 other lines. Is blue a transversal, is it the only one?
explanations.B: Transversals intersect with at least 2 other lines. Is red a transversal, is it the only one?
explanations.C: Transversals intersect with at least 2 other lines. Both the blue and red intersect with two other lines, so are both transversals.
explanations.D: Transversals intersect with at least 2 other lines. At least one of these is a transversal.

explanations.A: Even though the lines are not parallel, these are still alternate angles (but are not equal)
explanations.B: Are any of the lines here parallel?
explanations.C: Are any of the lines here parallel?
explanations.D: Usually we use alternate angle facts on parallel lines, but "alternate" is defined even if the lines aren't parallel.

explanations.A: Even though the lines are not parallel, these are still alternate angles (but are not equal). Therefore Tom is correct
explanations.B: Think carefully about where angles need to be to be alternate. What do we need in order to use parallel line facts?
explanations.C: Think carefully about where angles need to be to be alternate. What do we need in order to use parallel line facts?
explanations.D: At least one person is correct. Think carefully about where angles need to be to be alternate. What do we need in order to use parallel line facts?

explanations.A: What kind of angle is 125? Is it bigger or smaller than a right angle?
explanations.D: Can you find any alternate, co-interior, corresponding or vertically opposite angles on the diagram?

explanations.A: What kind of angle is 79? Is it bigger or smaller than a right angle?
explanations.D: Can you find any alternate, co-interior, corresponding or vertically opposite angles on the diagram?

explanations.A: Co-interior angles are sometimes called "C" or "U" angles. Corresponding angles are sometimes called "F" angles.
explanations.B: Corresponding angles are equal, but co-interior angles add to 180
explanations.C: Co-interior angles are sometimes called "C" or "U" angles. If one is acute, what is the other?
explanations.D: Corresponding angles are sometimes called "F" angles and are in matching corners.

explanations.A: Co-interior angles are on the inside of a U shape. Can you use other angle facts to find relationships between the angles?
explanations.B: Co-interior angles are on the inside of a U shape, so they are not co-interior. p is corresponding to the angle next to q, and they would form a straight line. Katie is correct, p + q = 180
explanations.C: At least one person is incorrect. Can you use angle facts to find relationships between the angles?
explanations.D: At least one person is correct. Can you use angle facts to find relationships between the angles?
